citeinfo.origin: United States Department of Commerce, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)
citeinfo.title: GeorgiaShoreline
citeinfo.othercit: This shoreline data set represents a vector conversion of NOAA National Ocean Service (NOS) shoreline (T-sheets) maps and CAD-based Standard Digital Data Exchange Format (SDDEF) data. These data were created by the National Ocean Service, National Geodetic Survey (previously the National Ocean Survey) as part of its ongoing mission to map the coastline of the United States. The NOAA National Ocean Service, Coastal Services Center developed the procedures used in this project and was responsible for project oversight. The project intent was to rescue valuable historical data and make it accessible and useful to digital mapping products. This file is a further conversion of that product from a raster to a vector product that may be useful for Electronic Charting and Display Information Systems (ECDIS) and geographic information systems (GIS).

descript.abstract: These data were automated to provide a suitable geographic information system (GIS) data layer depicting the historical shoreline for Georgia. These data are derived from shoreline maps that were produced by the NOAA National Ocean Service including its predecessor agencies.
descript.purpose: Shoreline spatial data are considered a crucial element in land use planning, determination of boundary extents, performing change analysis for erosion and accretion studies, and other types of decision making.

sngdate.caldate: REQUIRED: The year (and optionally month, or month and day) for which the data set corresponds to the ground.

idinfo.useconst: These data were generated for use by NGS during the course of its development of potential final products to fulfill its statutory mission. Although NGS is making these data available to others who may find the data of value, NGS does not warrant, endorse, or recommend the use of these data for any given purpose. The user assumes the entire risk related to the use of these data. These data are not for navigational purposes. NGS is providing these data "as is," and NGS disclaims any and all warranties, whether expressed or implied, including (without limitation) any implied warranties of merchantability or fitness for a particular purpose. In no event will NGS be liable to you or to any third party for any direct, indirect, incidental, consequential, special, or exemplary damages or lost profits resulting from any use or misuse of these data.

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows 2000 Version 5.2 (Build 3790) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.1850

attracc.attraccr: The attribute accuracy was tested by creating checkplots of the coded linework. The different codes depict shoreline, piers, dikes, jetties, breakwaters, and groins. A light table review of the checkplots would reveal any inaccurate coding. Mistakes would be identified and corrected until accurate checkplots were produced. The feature codes (f-codes) are identified as follows: Shoreline (1); Inland limit of mangrove swamp (6); Perinnial drainage, canal, or ditch (18); Jetty, breakwater, or groin (27); Pier, ramp, or dock (30); Bare part of marine railway (39); Canal (each side depicted (58); Dam (65); Class I structure intact (73); Class II structure intact (74); Structure in ruins (260); Structure under construction - (bridge, pier)(454); Fence (as an alongshore obstruction)(483); Levee, dike, or embankment (single line)(865); User added arc (-9999); Dike, levee, jetty, breakwater, groin, or pier not labeled (-9998); State boundary (-9997); State water (-9996)

dataqual.logic: Linework was vectorized to the neatline of the shoreline map. All data crossing the neatline was clipped to the neatline. All arcs were snapped by the nodes to create consistently tied strings without node dangles.
dataqual.complete: These shoreline data adequately represented the shoreline at the time of the survey.

horizpa.horizpar: The horizontal positional accuracy for the digital data was tested by producing checkplots of the vectorized data and overlaying it with a plot of the rasterized T-Sheet on a light table. Linework which appeared to be greater than a pen width off of the T-Sheet was considered in error, and revisions were made until new checkplots revealed an accurate depiction of the T-Sheet. For the SDDEF data, no accuracy assessment was made since CSC received this information directly from NOAA-NGS.

citeinfo.origin: United States Department of Commerce, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Ocean Service (NOS), National Geodetic Survey (NGS)
citeinfo.title: Vectorized Shoreline of Georgia Derived from NOAA-NOS Coastal Survey Maps Developed from 1933 - 1994 Source Data

pubinfo.publish: United States Department of Commerce, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Ocean Service (NOS), National Geodetic Survey (NGS)

citeinfo.othercit: These data were created by the National Ocean Service, National Geodetic Survey (previously the National Ocean Survey) as part of its ongoing mission to map the coastline of the United States. The NOAA National Ocean Service, Coastal Services Center developed the procedures used in this project and was responsible for project oversight. The project intent was to rescue valuable historical data and make it accessible and useful to digital mapping products. This file is a further conversion of that product from a raster to a vector product that may be useful for Electronic Charting and Display Information Systems (ECDIS) and geographic information systems (GIS).

srcinfo.srccontr: Used as backdrop for shoreline vectorization effort.

procstep.procdesc: During the vectorization process, all adjoining shoreline maps in the project are displayed on a computer screen and the shoreline is traced and coded appropriately. Maps within a project generally adjoin and, therefore, there is significant agreement of linework across the borders of the shoreline maps. This results in fewer errors related to the edge-matching process. Polygon labels and attributes are assigned to features containing area so that users may shade the data to determine land and water. All lines are coded with the feature code (f-code) value, a feature name (f-name), the shoreline map number (t/tp-sheet#), the scale of the shoreline map, the survey date, and the date the spatial data were captured. After the edgematching process is complete, the state boundary of Georgia was added, as was a one-degree buffer of the shoreline on the seaward side. This allowed for polygons to be created and attributed with the appropriate feature name (land/water). A 15-minute graticule was then overlayed onto the spatial data so that faster draw speeds of the data could be achieved. Lastly, the data were projected into the North American Datum(NAD) of 1983.
